. *recodes;
. gen droppedout=1*(dropout_dummy==2);

. sum dropout_dummy;

-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
dropout_du~y |      4299    1.146313    .3534609          1          2

. sum droppedout;

    Variable |       Obs        Mean    Std. Dev.       Min        Max
-------------+--------------------------------------------------------
  droppedout |      4299    .1463131    .3534609          0          1

. gen fracbet=bet/earnings;

. gen fracexpect=psexpectation/winpc;
(382 missing values generated)

. gen overconf=psexpectation-winpc;

. sort subjectid raceid;

. by subjectid raceid: egen dropoutfrac=mean(droppedout);

. sort subjectid raceid pitstopid;

. by subjectid raceid: gen runsumdropout=sum(droppedout);

. *recode expectations vars to be sensibly magnituded;
. gen expectation_r=expectation/100;

.  *interp in regressions:  one-unit change means car was expected to win one more "time out of ten";
. gen psexpectation_r=psexpectation/100;

.  *interp in regressions:  one-unit change means car was expected to win one more "time out of ten";
. gen winpc_r=winpc*10;

.  *interp in regressions:  one-unit change means car was actually likely to win one more "time out of ten";
. gen expectconf=psexpectation_r*psconfidence;
(1 missing value generated)

.  *the higher this is, the higher and stronger the expectation;

. *just take pitstop observations for people who either never dropped out, or are just dropping out for the first time within the particular race;
. *(to avoid "sore loser" or "sour grapes" effects of dropout behavior on expectations);
. *Note that we expect those who dropped out already to underestimate success in future pitstops;
. *therefore that their inclusion should have been artificially pushing the coefficient downwards - which is what we find (but a "true" effect remains);
. preserve;

. keep if (dropoutfrac==0)|((runsumdropout==1)*(droppedout==1));
(530 observations deleted)
